 4-109  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   4.2.12 Weight History (WHQ)  
The weight history section includes questions on weight perception in children and adolescents ages 8-15 
and if they are trying to do anything about their weight. WHQ is not administered if the interview is 
conducted with a proxy or if the interview is conducted with an interpreter that is a relative, neighbor, or 
friend. 
One in six children and adolescents 2-19 years of age in the U.S. is now overweight. Overweight children 
have a 70 percent chance of becoming overweight or obese adults. High cholesterol and high blood 
pressure, risk factors for heart disease, occur with increased frequency in overweight children and 
adolescents compared to children with a healthy weight. The child overweight trends pose significant 
health and financial burden for our children and the Nation. A related problem has to do with weight 
loss practices. Children and adolescents are especially prone to fad diets and eating disorders. Unhealthy 
methods of weight loss can compromise growth and are not recommended by health care professionals. 
The NHANES is the first to provide national data on weight perception in children and adolescents. The 
information from this section will be used with sociodemographic and related nutrition and health information to develop public policies and programs to prevent and manage overweight among children and adolescents. 
 
WHQ030C  The first item in this section asks SPs to indicate whether they consider themselves 
overweight, underweight, or the right weight. We are interested in the SPs’ perception of 
their weight, not what they may have been told by someone else. 
 
WHQ500  WHQ500 obtains information about whether an SP is currently trying to lose weight, gain 
weight, or maintain their weight. There is also an option for SPs to report that they’re not 
actively engaging in any type of weight control or loss practices.

prepared somewhere other than at home or as part of the school lunch/breakfast program. Meals include breakfast, lunch, or dinner. Do not include snacks. Please remember to read

sources of meals they need to consider when answering the question. 
 If asked, school meals from “a la carte” counters or from vending machines that are not

home. Frozen meals eaten at home count as meals prepared at a home. Fully cooked foods 
(such as a roast chicken) from a deli counter count as meals not prepared at a home. 
However, if only the chicken is bought at a deli, but the rest of the foods were prepared at 
home, the meal should be counted as prepared in a home. Leftovers from a restaurant that

 Note: Meals prepared at “a” home, which does not have to be the SP’s own home, still 
count as meals prepared at home. Therefore, a meal eaten at a grandmother’s or friend’s house counts as a meal prepared at home. 
 The unit of interest is the number of times in past 7 days. If the SP reports that he or she 
never eats meals that are prepared outside a home, code “2” in the first data field. 
Otherwise, code “1” in the first data field, press “Enter” to enable the second data field and 
type in the number of meals in the past 7 days.

 4-119  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   4.3 Cognitive Functioning: Montreal Cognitive Ass essment – 
Survey Adapted (60 years +) 
Cognitive health has emerged as an important public health concern, most notably for the nation’s aging 
population (1,2). Impaired cognitive functioning has been associated with declines in quality of life, 
personal relationships and independence. It also has resulted in increased health care needs, major 
caregiving and financial challenges (3). Among the non-institutionalized population of older adults, 
understanding all levels of cognitive ability including early, subclinical cognitive loss is of special interest 
because of the association of cognition with psychological, social or physical measures (4). New insights 
into the risk factors for the subtle variations in cognitive performance can assist in targeting behavioral and clinical interventions . 
The Montreal Cognitive Assessment – Survey Adapted (MoCA-SA) was developed for a large, 
population-based survey, the National Social life, Health and Aging Project (NSHAP) (5) by a team at 
the University of Chicago. It is a modified version of the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA), a standardized clinical instrument designed primarily to assess mild cognitive impairment (6). The MoCA-SA contains 14 short exercises and covers eight cognitive domains: orientation, naming, executive 
function, visuo-spatial skills, memory, attention, language, and abstraction (5). Scores range from 0 to 20 
and can be scaled for comparison with the original MOCA scores of 0 to 30, using a prediction equation (7). The instrument was designed to be administered by non-medical personnel (7) and is available at no 
cost. 
The MEC Interviewers will both conduct and score the assessments. The MEC interviews are recorded, 
therefore, the full scoring of the MOCA-SA will not occur while the assessment is conducted. For the first time since NHANES has had a cognitive performance component, overall scores will be included 
with other MEC examination results in the SP’s final Report of Findings. The Report of Findings are 
mailed approximately 8 weeks after the examinations are completed.  
In addition, two specific MoCA-SA tasks will be scored while conducting the assessment. SPs who fail 
these two specific MoCA-SA tasks will be automatically referred to the MEC physician for a possible 
referral. Only details for the two items scored during the assessments are discussed in this chapter, while explicit instructions for scoring all of the tasks are found in Chapter 7. 
1. Alzheimer’s Association and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The Healthy 
Brain Initiative: The Public Health Road Map for State and National Partnerships, 2013–2018: Chicago, IL: Alzheimer’s Association; 2013.    
 4-120  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   2. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The Healthy Brain Initiative: The Public 
Health Road Map for State and National Partnerships, 2013-2018, Interim Progress Report; Atlanta, GA: CDC, 2015. Available from: https://www.cdc.gov/aging/pdf/2013-healthy-
brain-initiative-interim-report.pdf  
3. Anderson LA, McConnell SR. Cognitive health: an emerging public health issue, Alzheimer’s & Dementia. 2007; S70-S73. 
4. Salthouse T. Consequences of age-related cognitive declines. Annual Review of Psychology. 2012; 63:201-226. 
5. Shega JW, Sunkara PD, Kotwal A, et al. Measuring cognition: the Chicago Cognitive Function Measure in the National Social Life, Health and Aging Project, Wave 2. J Gerotol B Psychol Sci Soci. 2014; 69(suppl2):S166-S176. 
6. Nasreddine ZS, Phillips NA, Bedirian V, et al. The Montreal Cognitive Assessment, 
MOCA: a brief screening instrument for classification of Alzheimers disease, mild cognitive 
impairment, and healthy aging. Alzheimers Dement 2013:9:529-537. 
7. Kotwal AA, Schumm LP, Kern DW et al. Evaluation of a brief survey instrument for 
assessing subtle differences in cognitive function among older adults. Alzheimer Dis Assoc 
Disorder 2015; 29(4): 317-324. 
4.3.1 General Instructions  
The Cognitive Functioning (CFQ) section will automatically be skipped for proxy interviews and if the 
SP speaks a language other than English or Spanish. 
Most of the screens in this section has either a question to answer or instructions about how to solve a 
problem. There are a few additional screens, including one related to the partial scoring of one of the tasks (e.g., clock drawings). The screens are numbered in the same way as a CAPI questionnaire section, but the screens that are specific to a question or problem to solve have a name. Because most of the 
items on the MoCA-SA are taken from other well-established cognitive assessments, the names of the 
task are provided here for ease of reference. The wording for the instructions for each item has not been 
altered from the MoCA-SA; however, bolding of certain words, as well as some interviewer instructions 
have been added. 
Just as reading each question exactly as it is written is critical throughout the interview, it is also critical 
that each SP receives the same instructions so that results are valid. If a mistake is made while reading the question, stop and read that particular sentence over. Instructions can only be repeated to the SP one 
time so interviewers must make sure they are reading slow, clear, and loud enough for the SP to hear the 
question. Probing outside of what is indicated on the screen and repeating the instructions more than    
 4-121 MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   once is prohibited to avoid assisting with the item or unduly affecting the response. (Please see the 
description of questions CFQ530, CFQ535, CFQ540, CFQ545, and CFQ555 for exceptions to repeating 
the instructions.) 
Interviewers may not coach the SP in any way. For paper and pencil exercises, it is critical for 
interviewers to avoid giving indications of whether or not the drawing is correct, including facial expression, hesitation, or other subtle clues. 
Each task is different and some are more difficult than others. An SP may do poorly on one exercise and 
very well on another. If the SP becomes frustrated after giving the question or problem a good try, or two, it is appropriate to say “Let’s move on;” however, be careful not to move on prematurely. It is not 
uncommon for SPs to become frustrated but with encouragement they are able to complete the task. SPs 
may not want to try because they don’t think they can do the exercise or they may be embarrassed that they are having trouble doing the exercise. Interviewers should encourage completion of the tasks without adding to the stress of the situation and should offer neutral phrases as support when subjects 
cannot complete the tasks. While we do not want to upset SPs by the task, interviewers must be careful 
not to say anything that would encourage the SP to quit or not try the task. 
Phrases to avoid Instead say 
You can stop anytime you want. Let’s give it a try. 
You don’t have to do it. You’re doing fine/alright. 
Do you want to stop? You have more time left. 
 
Effort plays a major role in these exercises so encourage SPs to try or keep going. Use nonverbal queues 
like head nodding to indicate they’re doing well. It is also okay to commend the SP as a form of encouragement. The goal should be for them not to give up just because one exercise is difficult. Multiple forms of encouragement can be used when necessary. SPs who can focus and give their best 
effort, tend to do better. As long as an SP is making an effort to complete the task, give them time to do 
so. For all questions in the assessment, mark “refused” if the SP refuses to try. Mark “don’t know” if the SP says they don’t know after asking them to guess or if they don’t make a guess. 
If necessary, you may refer to this section as an exercise or activity, but do not use the word “test” in the 
presence of an SP. Score sheets and notes should not be placed within the SP’s view. 
Once the respondent has chosen to have the assessment conducted in English or Spanish, the 
interviewer must conduct the entire assessment in that language.    
 4-122  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   NHANES participants may be familiar with specific exercises because certain MoCA-SA questions and 
tasks are the same as those found on other well-known cognitive functioning assessments. Some SPs 
may have had a doctor administer the full MoCA during a regular visit for a physical or while in the 
hospital. The SP may mention this during the assessment, but that really should not matter, and you can simply nod your head and smile, or acknowledge with an ‘ok’ reply. 
4.3.2 Recording and Using the Microphone  
The entire CFQ section is recorded. Recording the SP’s responses using a microphone allows the interviewer to pay close attention to the examinee without having the burden of recording the responses 
by hand. The SP’s responses will be scored using the recordings at a later time. 
On the permission to record screen, there are visual cues that will indicate that the system has checked to 
make sure everything is ready to record. A green check mark indicates that the system has checked that item and it is working. A red check mark indicates that the system has checked that item and it is not 
working. If any item has not passed the check, troubleshoot and fix the problem before proceeding. 
 
SPs’s
 tend to speak softer when they have trouble remembering, therefore, before starting, make sure the 
microphone is positioned no more than a 1 foot away from the SP. Recording tips to remember: 
• Turn off or turn down the sound machine in the room. If you are picking up noise from the 
hall or the neighboring room, it is okay to turn the sound machine on but put it a the lowest 
level need to reduce the distraction. If you don’t need the sound machine, turn it off for this 
section. 
• If the SP is soft-spoken, position the microphone closer to the SP. 
• You may also need to ask soft-spoken SPs to speak louder so the microphone can pick up his or her responses. Pointing at the microphone can be used as a non-verbal reminder that they need to speak louder because we are recording. 
• Don’t allow the SP’s to speak directly into the microphone. Being too close to the microphone can cause the recording to be distorted.    
 4-123  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   During recordings, the interviewer should avoid making affirmative sounds after every word the SP says. 
This could interfere with the scorer’s ability to hear what the SP said when they listen to the recording.

 4-125  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   4.3.3 CFQ Questions and Exercise Screens  
SPs’s 60 years and older will receive a slightly different permission to record statement introduction and 
consent for the interview because they are eligible for the CFQ section. (Section 6.2.1) 
CFQ500 This is the introduction for the MoCA-SA. It explains what to expect from the test and 
instructs participants not use clues from around the room to help. Some of the exercises 
may require the SP to use his/her glasses. Ask the SP if he/she usually wears glasses to read. 
If they do, make sure the SP has the glasses nearby so you don’t lose any time once the assessment begins. Each MEC Interviewer room is stocked with 4 pair of reading glasses of 
various strenghts if the SP doesn’t have their glasses available. Help the SP figure out the 
correct strength before beginning the assessment. 
 
   
CFQ501 ORIENTATION – MONTH. 
 TASK: You will ask the SP to state the month. 
 This is the first question in the assessment and is one of two questions that are scored 
during the assessment. The correct month will be programmed automatically and shown on the screen. 
• If the SP says the number of the month instead of the name of the month, that is 
acceptable. Code the SP’s response as correct or incorrect. 
• If the SP says the entire date for this question, that is okay, however, you are coding the “month” portion of the response as correct or incorrect for this question. 
     
 4-126  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020    
 
 
    
  
   
 4-127  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   CFQ505 ORIENTATION – DATE.  
 TASK: Ask the SP to state the date, meaning the day of the month. 
• It is possible that the SP gave both the month and the date when answering the 
previous question. Since it is our policy in MEC Interview to read every question, we will read the question and confirm their response by saying something like “You answered this in the last question but I need to read the question and confirm. Tell 
me the exact date. You said the 19
th. Is that correct?” This allows the SP to change 
their answer or stick with their original answer. 
• If the SP gives multiple dates (i.e. 14th, 15th, 16th) it is acceptable to say that you can 
only accept a single date. You might say, “take a little time to think about it.” 
• If the SP says something similar to “I can’t remember without my phone” or attempts to look at his/her watch, which may have the date, ask them to take a little 
time to think about it and then make their best guess. 
 The interviewer will not code the SP’s response on this screen. Simply enter “1” to 
continue. 
CFQ510 ANIMAL NAMING.  
 TASK: You will ask the SP to name an animal in the picture. Place Picture #1 on the table in front of the SP, then read the statement on the screen. 
• If English is not the SP’s first language, he/she may tell you that they don’t know the 
name of the animal in English. Ask the SP what language they speak and to say the 
name of the animal in his/her language. After the SP has responded, enter “1” to continue.  
• If the SP gives more than one response (i.e., it’s a hippo or a rhino), ask the SP to “choose one” or say “which one is it?”. If they respond a second time with more than one answer, do not probe further. Move on to the next question.  
     
 4-128  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020    
 
    
 
    
 
 
  
   
 4-129  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   CFQ515 CLOCK DRAWING.  
 TASK: This is the first of two exercises that require paper and pencil. You will be asking the 
SP to draw a clock with the hands set to a specific time. If you have not done so already, 
fold the exercise sheet in half before reading the instructions for the question. 
• Read the first sentence on the screen and then pause, and place a pencil and CFQ 
exercise paper in front of the SP with the top edge of the paper closest to you so that 
when the paper is unfolded for scanning, the drawing will be in the correct direction. Then, continue reading the instructions that states the time for the clock face. Only read the prompt if the SP starts to look around for clues (i.e. watch, cell phone). Note: If the SP asks you to repeat the time he/she must draw, you may do it one time.  
• Pay close attention to the SP while he/she is completing the exercise. When the SP has completed the task, take the paper and pencil away from the SP.  
• If the SP looked at a watch or cell phone to help them with the exercise, code this response category.  
• It is acceptable for the SP to cross out a drawing, or to redraw the clock multiple times, if self-initiated.  If the SP indicates in any way (including body language) that they have made a mistake, tell them that it’s okay to erase. Keep in mind that if they make a correction without erasing, it will be impossible for the 2
nd scorer and those 
performing QC checks to figure out what lines are correct.  
 CFQ520 THE CLOCK DRAWING-CONTOUR SCORE. The clock drawing has three parts: 
the contour (i.e. face), the numbers and the hands. Here, you are asked to look at the drawing and determine whether the contour of the clock is drawn correctly. To be correct: 
the contour of the clock may only have minor distortion. For example, a slight 
imperfection on closing the circle is acceptable. (See Chapter 7 for more details about 
acceptable and unacceptable clock contours). Score the face of the clock only as correct or incorrect. 
     
 4-130  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020    
 
    
 
  
  
   
 4-131  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   CFQ525 ALTERNATE TRAIL MAKING.  
 TASK: This is the second pencil and paper exercise and requires asking the SP to draw lines 
between circles, alternating between numbers and letters in ascending order. 
• Place the CFQ exercise paper in front of the SP. Then read the first sentence which 
asks the SP to take a minute to look over the paper. Pause and give the SP ample time to do so.  
• Read the instructions exactly as they are written on the screen, slowly and deliberately. As you read the instructions, point to the specific numbers and letters on the page as indicated on the screen.  
• Do not draw on the dotted lines when explaining the exercise to the SP.  
• It is acceptable for the respondent to erase his or her first attempt and try again, as long as this is initiated entirely by the SP with no input or feedback from the interviewer. As with the clock exercise, if the SP indicates in any way (including body language) that they have made a mistake, tell them that it’s okay to erase.  
 When the SP has completed the task, code on the screen if the SP made no corrections or 
self-corrected mistakes by erasing . 
 
CFQ525 
cont’d This is the alternate trail making exercise that the SP is asked to complete. 
 
     
 4-132  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020    
 
 
 
     
 
  
  
   
 4-133  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   CFQ530 MEMORY – IMMEDIATE RECALL TRIAL 1.  
 TASK: Five words are read aloud to the SP and immediate recall of the words is requested. 
• Read the instructions, and then read the words at a rate of one word per second. 
Words should be read slowly and clearly.  
• If the SP starts repeating each word immediately after you say it, instruct him/her to wait until you’ve said all of the words before repeating them.  
• If the SP does not start repeating the words when you have finished reading them, prompt the SP using the statement on the screen.  
• If you have to repeat the instructions, you may do so one time, however, the list of words may not be repeated.  
• If an SP indicates that they did not hear a word immediately after you say it, you may 
repeat it but you may not repeat it under any other condition.  
• Do not correct the SP if he/she says a word that was not a target word or if the SP says a word that sounds like a target word (i.e. faith instead of face).  
• It is appropriate to respond to questions like “Did I say that one?” by saying things 
like “That’s fine” or “That’s okay. Keep going.” When the SP has recalled all of the 
words or indicates that he/she cannot recall any more words, move on to the next screen (you can say, “let’s move on,” but not in a rushed way).  
 CFQ535  MEMORY – IMMEDIATE RECALL TRIAL 2.  
 TASK: The five words are read for a second time and an immediate recall of the words is 
requested once again. The same guidelines used in Immediate Recall Trial 1 should be 
followed. 
 On the next screen (CFQ540), SPs are informed that they will be asked to recall these 
words again later on. It is important for the SP to acknowledge this directive. After reading 
the statement, pause and make eye contact. 
     
 4-134  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020    
 
  
  
   
 4-135  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   CFQ540 DIGIT SPAN – FORWARD ORDER.  
 TASK: Five numbers are read aloud to the SP and immediate recall is requested. 
• Read the instruction and then read the five numbers at a rate of one digit per second.  
• If the SP doesn’t start repeating the numbers, read the prompt on the screen.  
• If you have to repeat the instructions, you may do so one time, however, the five 
numbers may not be repeated.  
     
 
  CFQ545 DIGIT SPAN – BACKWARD ORDER.  
 TASK: Three numbers are read aloud to the SP and backward recall is the requested. 
• Read the instructions slowly and clearly and emphasize the word “backward.” Pause and read the numbers at a rate of one digit per second.  
• If the SP doesn’t start repeating the numbers, read the prompt on the screen.  
• If the SP repeats the numbers in the forward order, do not correct the SP and do not indicate in any way that the SP has incorrectly followed the instructions.  
• If you have to repeat the instructions, you may do so one time, however, the three numbers may not be repeated.  
     
 4-136  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020    
 
  
   
 4-137  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   CFQ550 SUBTRACTION – SERIAL 7s.  
 TASK: The SP is asked to subtract 7 from 100 and to keep counting down by 7. 
 This requires mental calculations and it is therefore unacceptable for the SP to use fingers 
or pencil and paper to help with the task. 
• The interviewer cannot repeat the SP’s responses nor directly answer questions 
regarding where the SP is in the process (see section 4.2.1.1). Answering such 
questions would affect the validity of the response. The exercise is timed, but SPs can take as much time as needed.  
• If an SP does not understand the part of the instruction, “keep counting down by seven”, it is acceptable for the interviewer to repeat the instructions once and say 
“keep subtracting by seven” instead, however, avoid repeating the instructions 
further to avoid coaching the respondent.  
• If the SP completes the first subtraction and stops, the interviewer may say “keep subtracting by seven” or “continue counting down by seven” but ONLY if the instructions have not already been repeated.  
• If the instructions have already been repeated, neutral probes like “you have more time”, “do you need more time?”, or “continue” are appropriate but cannot be used after every response.  
• After instructing the SP, start the timer. Stop the SP after five numbers are reported (not including 100), but don’t cut them off if he/she is in the process of telling you another number.  
• If the SP gives up or says he/she wants to stop before reaching five numbers, it is acceptable to encourage them by saying “you have time”, or “keep going; you are doing ok.”.  
• Stop the timer when the SP reaches the fifth number or when they give up. Record the number of seconds on the timer and continue to the next question.  
     
 4-138  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020    
 
 
  
   
 4-139  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   CFQ555 SENTENCE REPETITION. 
 TASK: The the SP will be asked to repeat a sentence exactly as you have read it to them. 
• Read the instruction on the screen slowly and clearly and emphasize the word 
“exactly.” Then read the sentence slowly enunciating each word in the sentence.  
• If SP doesn’t start repeating the sentence on their own, use the prompt on the screen.  
• If you have to repeat the instructions, you may do so one time, however, the 
sentence may not be repeated.  
      
 4-140  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020     
   
 4-141  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   CFQ560 VERBAL FLUENCY – LETTER F.  
 TASK: The SP will be asked to say as many words as they can think of that start with the 
letter F. This exercise is timed for 1 minute. 
• This task has a long set of instructions. Read the instructions, pausing at the end of 
each sentence. After asking if the SP is ready and he/she indicates readiness, start the timer. When the allotted time has passed, stop the SP and continue to the next exercise.  
• This question includes a probe. If you have to read the “probe if necessary” statement, it counts as reading the instruction for the second time.  
• Read the instructions as written without adding anything. After reading the 
instructions the first time, avoid asking the SP “do you understand”, “do you have 
questions,” or “does that make sense”. The instructions already include the statement “Are you ready?” If the SP has questions at that time or indicate that they don’t understand, you can read the “probe if necessary” statement provided.  
• If the SP stops and seems to have given up but there is still time left, encourage him/her to keep going until the full 60 seconds are up by saying “You have more 
time left,” repeat the phrase “as many as you can think of,” and/or use a hand 
gesture indicating to keep going. It is not unusual for SPs to want to give up when they can’t think of any more words. The goal is to not let the SP give up just because the words aren’t coming to them rapidly. 
• If the SP names two consecutive  words that begin with another letter of the alphabet 
(that is NOT the letter F), repeat the part of the instructions that mentions the target letter, if the instructions have not been repeated already. If the instructions have already been repeated, allow the SP to continue but do not repeat the part of the instructions that states the target letter.  
• If the SP clearly did not understand the instructions and isn’t performing the test 
appropriately, an exception may be made and the interviewer may repeat the 
instructions once more. This is rare situation and must not be used just because the SP is responding incorrectly. An example of when this exception could be used is if the SP is only saying proper nouns and names. If the SP still continues to 
respond incorrectly, allow the SP to continue but do not repeat the instructions again.  
     
 4-142  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020    
 
    
 
    
 
   
  
   
 4-143  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   CFQ565  ABSTRACTION – ALIKE. 
 TASK: SPs are asked to indicate how two items are alike, and are asked to think abstractly 
about their likeness, that is, to think about how they are both in the same category. An 
example is first provided with some guidance, and then the “real” question is asked without 
further assistance. 
 The interviewer reads the first question (the example) following the instructions on the 
screen before beginning the exercise. The interviewer is guided through possible SP 
responses: 
• If the SP gives the correct response, reinforce the abstract thinking by saying “Yes, 
they are both fruit.”  
• If the SP gives a concrete response (i.e. they both have peels, they are both good to eat, or both are sweet), give one additional prompt – “Tell me another way in which those items are alike.” If the SP does not give the appropriate response, you will say, “Yes, and they are also both fruit.” No additional instructions or clarification should be given.  
• If an SP does not understand the word “alike”, it is acceptable to use the word “same” to improve comprehension if language is a barrier.  
 Once you have given instructions for the exercise, do not give any additional instructions or 
prompts. 
 
CFQ570 MEMORY – DELAYED RECALL.  
 TASK: In the final exercise, SPs are asked to repeat words that they heard read aloud and 
recalled earlier (2 separate times). Read the instructions as written on the screen slowly and 
deliberately. 
• If the SP starts to recall the sentence about cats instead of the list of words or starts 
to try to recall the F words, you may repeat the instructions once more (if they have 
not already been repeated). Do not make any comments, like, “those aren’t the words 
I’m talking about.”  
     
 4-144  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020    
  
   
 4-145  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   CFQ575 POST TEST COMMENTS. 
 This is a field for the interviewers only. Please take your time and code all that apply These 
are comments for you to code based on what you observed during the assessment or 
remarks made by SPs. 
 Some codes explained: 
• SP REPORTED COGNITIVE PROBLEMS: Select this code if SP commented 
during the assessment that he/she is forgetful, have trouble remembering things, or that a doctor has said that he/she has a cognitive impairment or condition.  
• SP REPORTED TAKING MEDICATIONS: Code if SP mentions during the assessment that he/she is taking medication for a cognitive problem or is taking a medication that causes confusion or fatigue making it hard to focus or concentrate.  
 Status When you advance to the section status screen, a SPID barcode label will automatically 
print. Immediately affix the label to the CFQ exercise sheet. Place the label in the upper right-hand corner of each sheet. At the end of the MEC Interview, scan the sheet as 
explained in Section 4.3.5. 
     
 4-146  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   4.3.4 Responding to Questions or Concerns  
Below are examples of how to respond to questions that may come up. 
Participant: “What does this test have to do with memory?” 
MEC Interviewer: “These questions are about problem solving and memory.” 
Participant: SP asks for confirmation that they are understanding the question correctly. For 
example, “You want me to draw a line from a number to a letter, correct?” 
MEC Interviewer: “I’m sorry, but I’m not permitted to answer questions about these items. I can repeat the instructions if you’d like.” 
Participant: “What number am I on?” or “How many more do I have to do?” 
MEC Interviewer: The interviewer may reply by repeating the instructions if the instructions have not 
already been repeated once before or say “I’m sorry, but I’m not permitted to answer that question. Just 
try to do the best you can.” 
Participant: “I feel like I don’t remember anything anymore.”  
MEC Interviewer: “Memory is affected by a number of factors like age, how much you sleep, 
medication, hormonal changes, and several medical conditions. If you worry about your memory, you should talk with your doctor about the problems you have been experiencing.” 
Participant: “Can you tell me how I did on these tests?” 
MEC Interviewer: “We are not able to score the exercises right away, however, you will receive your results in your final report of findings in the mail. If you worry about your memory, you should talk with 
your doctor about the problems you have been experiencing.” 
     
 4-147  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   4.3.5 Scanning the CFQ Exercise Sheet  
The CFQ exercise sheets cannot be scanned during the MEC Interview. After the interview is closed, 
scan the CFQ exercise sheet by clicking on “Utilities” and “Scan CFQ forms.” Coding sheets should be 
scanned as soon as possible after the interview is complete. If you are not able to scan the document immediately after the interview, place it in the left pocket of the CFQ folder and scan it at the first 
available opportunity (Exhibit 4-1). 
Exhibit 4 -1. Accessing the scanning feature  
 
A box will appear that lists SPs who have CFQ exercise sheets that have not been scanned (Exhibit 4-2). 
Only SPs from the current session will appear in this list. To display a list of SPs from previous sessions, 
click the “Show SPs from All Sessions” check box in the top right corner.    
 4-148  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   Exhibit 4 -2. CFQ exercise sheets that have not been scanned  
 
Scan the barcode on the CFQ exercise sheet. A “scan and save” box will appear on the ISIS screen 
(Exhibit 4-3). Align the paper with the scanner (print side down and against the right-hand corner) and 
click “Scan” on the ISIS screen. 
Exhibit 4 -3. CFQ Scan and Save  
    
 4-149  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   Once scanning is complete, the image will appear on the ISIS screen (Exhibit 4-4). Scroll up and down, 
left and right to review the quality of the image. Click “save” to save the image or “rescan” to remove 
the current image and scan the document again. 
Exhibit 4 -4. Example of a scanned image  
 
When you click “save” you will receive a message indicating that the image was successfully saved. Put the scanned exercise sheet in the right pocket of the CFQ folder. All forms will be returned to the home 
office at the end of the stand.

 Screen The middle portion of the screen consists of two questions. The responses to these two 
questions allow the application to properly skip the ACASI section based on the interview

 It is critical that each SP be given the opportunity to complete ACASI. Do not assume that

course of the CAPI interview, it appeared as though the SP could have completed the

 4-152  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   This page intentionally left blank. 
     
 4-153  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   4.4 Audio -CASI Sections of the MEC Interview  
The audio-CASI section of the MEC interview consists of five sections of questions, which are asked in 
this format because they contain sensitive topics. Research on the mode of interview indicates that respondents will be more honest and forthcoming in their answers if they can answer a self-administered 
mode. The audio-CASI allows SPs to both hear and read the questions and to move at their own speed 
through the sections as they touch the computer screen to indicate their response. 
This method of administration is thought to be especially effective in eliciting answers from young 
people. Therefore, audio-CASI is used to administer tobacco and alcohol use questions to SPs aged 12 to 
17. 
SPs aged 12 to 59 receive the section on drug use and SPs aged 14 to 69 receive the sexual behavior 
section in audio-CASI.

 4-160  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020    
 
 
Non-Response Screen 
 
   
 4-161  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   The specifications that follow are intended to assist you in answering questions that an SP may have in 
the course of responding to the computer-managed questioning. 
Non-
response Screen The audio-CASI is designed not to provide the respondent with an obvious option of stating that they don’t know an answer or refusing to answer. However, there is a nonresponse option for the SP. This option exists in the form of a second screen which appears if the SP presses the “Next” button on the screen without answering the question. 
The screen will present SPs with three options: the first, that they really meant to answer the 
question; second, that they would rather not answer; and third, that they don’t know the answer. Choosing the first response will take the SP back to the original question, while 
choosing the second or third option will skip the SP forward to the next appropriate 
question. If the SP goes back to a previous question to which they answered “I’d rather not answer” or “I don’t know the answer,” the answer categories will be unselected and if the SP decides to answer the question, they can simply select a response.

 4-163  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   4.4.2 Tobacco (SMQ)  
The questions in this section cover smoking history and current tobacco use. SPs 12-17 years of age are 
asked tobacco questions in the audio-CASI section of the interview. 
SMQ621_ This section introduces the Tobacco section. Touch “Next” to proceed to the first 
question. 
 
   
 
 SMQ621 This question asks about the number of cigarettes smoked in the SP’s entire life. 
Respondents who have not smoked a whole cigarette are skipped to SMQ680.    
 4-164  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   SMQ631 
 
 
SMQ641 
  
 
SMQ050 
    
 4-165  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   SMQ631 This item asks for the age when the sample person first smoked a cigarette. Respondents 
can enter any age up to and including their age at the time of the interview. Respondents are 
instructed to enter zero if they never smoked a whole cigarette. Subjects who have never 
smoked a whole cigarette skip to SMQ680. 
 
 
 
 SMQ641 This question is important to quantify the SP’s smoking habit by asking the number of days 
he or she actually smoked over the month prior to the interview. 
 If the SP did not smoke cigarettes in the past 30 days, he or she is instructed to enter a zero. 
The program then skips to SMQ670. 
 
 
  SMQ050 If the SP has not smoked cigarettes in the past 30 days, they are asked how long it has been 
since he or she quit smoking.    
 4-166  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   SMQ055 
 
 
SMQ650 
  
 
SMQ078 
    
 4-167  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   SMQ055 The SP is asked for the age when he or she last smoked cigarettes if he or she has not 
smoked a cigarette in over a year. 
 
   
 
 
SMQ650 This question is important to establish the current intensity of the SPs smoking habit. The 
SP is asked, on the days that he or she smoked, for the average number of cigarettes 
smoked. 
 
 
   
SMQ078 This is the second question that establishes the intensity of the SP’s habit. Current smokers 
are asked to indicate how soon after they wake up they smoke.

SMQ681_ 
 
SMQ682

smoking. 
 
   
 
 
SMQ681_ Introductory screen

current users of smoking tobacco products. 
 Subjects who respond other than “Yes” skip to questions about e-cigarettes.    
 4-170  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   SMQ692A 
  
 
SMQ692B 
     
 4-171  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   SMQ692A If the SP reports having used any type of smoking tobacco product in the past 5 days, this 
question asks the SP to specify which types of products he or she has used. The remainder 
of this question series follows up with questions appropriate only to those products the SP 
reports using in the past 5 days. The “past 5 days” refers to the current day and the 4 days immediately preceding the interview. 
 
 
 
 
SMQ692B SPs who reported smoking less than one cigarette in his or her lifetime or no cigarettes in 
the past 30 days, receive this alternate form of the question.    
 4-172  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   SMQ710 
 
 
SMQ720 
 
 
SMQ725 
    
 4-173  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   SMQ710 This question quantifies the smoker’s current use of cigarettes. SPs should count the 
number of days in the 4 days immediately before the interview and the day of the interview 
that they smoked cigarettes, even if they took only a few puffs. 
 
  
 
 
SMQ720 This question is asked of all current cigarette smokers to determine the number of 
cigarettes, not packs, smoked in the past 5 days. We are interested in the average number of 
cigarettes smoked per day, only for those days in the past five that the respondent smoked. 
If the respondent indicates that he or she smokes more than 95 cigarettes per day on average, the program will store a response of “95.” The “95” response is visible to the SP 
only if the SP backs up to review his or her response. 
 
 
 
SMQ725 This question asks the respondent to indicate when in the past 5 days he or she last smoked 
a cigarette.    
 4-174  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   SMQ740 
 
 
SMQ771 
  
 
SMQ845 
    
 4-175  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   SMQ740 If the respondent indicated that he or she smoked a pipe in the past 5 days, he or she will be 
asked this question. Refer to the specifications from SMQ710. 
 
   
 
 
SMQ771 If the respondent indicated that he or she smoked a cigar, little cigar, or cigarillo in the past 
5 days, he or she will be asked this question. Refer to the specifications from SMQ710. 
 Traditional cigars contain lightly rolled cured tobacco that is wrapped in a tobacco leaf. 
Cigarillos and little cigars are smaller than traditional cigars. Some are the same size as 
cigarettes and some come with plastic or wooden tips. Common brands are Black and Mild, 
Swisher Sweets, Dutch Master, Phillies Blunts, Prime Time and Winchester. 
 
 
SMQ845 If the respondent indicated that he or she smoked tobacco in a water pipe or hookah in the 
past 5 days, he or she will be asked this question. Refer to the specifications from SMQ710.  
 A hookah is a water pipe with a smoke chamber, a bowl, a pipe and a hose. Tobacco (often 
flavored) is heated, and the smoke passes through water and is then drawn through a rubber 
hose to a mouthpiece. There are many types of hookahs. People often smoke in groups in cafes or in hookah bars.

 4-183  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   4.4.3 Alcohol Use (ALQ) 
This section obtains information on the use of alcohol. Sample persons 12-17 years are asked alcohol-
related questions in the audio-CASI format. 
ALQ010_ This screen introduces the section and provides the SP with a definition of a drink. A 
“drink” is essentially, what the SP considers a drink to be; for example, a glass or can of 
beer, a glass of wine, a shot of hard liquor, or a mixed drink. It does not include drinking 
small amounts of wine for religious purposes. 
 
 
ALQ022 This question obtains information on how many days in the SP’s life he/she has had at least one drink of alcohol. If the SP reports drinking “0 days,” he/she will skip to the end of the section. 
 
  
 
 ALQ010 This question obtains information on when a respondent had his or her first drink of 
alcohol other than just a few sips. The SP is presented with several age ranges.

 4-187  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   4.4.4 Drug Use (DUQ)  
This section is administered to SPs aged 12 to 59 years. The questions focus on lifetime and regular 
use of marijuana and hashish and street or recreational drugs, as well as, the intravenous use of these drugs. Additional questions on age of initiation of specific drugs, how long since last used, and frequency of use in the past 30 days are included in this section. No measurements for the presence of drug metabolites will be conducted. The use of drugs has been demonstrated to be a risk factor for sexuall y transmitted diseases. Injection drug use is also a risk for blood borne pathogens such as 
HIV, HBV, and HCV. Researchers will use the information on drug use along with sexual behavior questions to develop a profile of risk-taking behavior. Questions were added to the 2009- 2010 
NHANES survey to determine “regular” use of marijuana and hashish. These data are collected as co-factors to look at the potential association between oral HPV and head and neck squamous cell 
carcinoma.  
 
DUQ200_ This screen introduces the section and reminds respondents that the information collected 
in the study is kept confidential. 
 
 
DUQ005 DUQ200 through DUQ235 obtain information on marijuana and cannabis use. This screen 
provides alternate terms that may be used to refer to marijuana or cannabis. 
 The first question of the section also appears on this screen. This question asks SPs how old they were the first time they used marijuana. 
 SPs who have never used marijuana skip to DUQ250. 
 
DUQ230 Only SPs who have used marijuana or cannabis are asked to report on how many days in 
the past 30 they used marijuana.

 4-201  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   4.4.5 Sexual Behavior (SXQ)  
Information on sexual behavior is key to reducing the risk of STDs, including acquired 
immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). Such behaviors include delaying onset of sexual intercourse by 
adolescents, minimizing number of sexual partners and utilizing barrier contraceptives. Participants 14-69 years are asked about types of sexual behavior they have participated in, age of first intercourse, 
number of total sexual partners, number of partners for specific types of sexual behavior, use of 
condoms, and history of sexually-transmitted diseases. (SPs 60-69 years old only receive select questions 
in this section.) The questions on sexual behavior are included to provide for: targeting risk reduction 
efforts; assessing the results of such effort, and improving current understanding of the epidemiology of 
STDs. Additional questions on oral sex are also included in order to assess associations between oral 
sexual behavior and oral HPV infection. SPs should report consensual and nonconsensual acts when responding to these questions. The Sexual Behavior questionnaire is split into two questionnaires, female 
and male. 
4.4.5.1 Female Sexual Behavior (SXQ)  
SXQ615_ This screen introduces the section. It provides a definition of sex to include vaginal, oral, or 
anal sex. The introduction includes a statement reassuring confidentiality, as the questions 
in this section deal with very private behaviors and issues. 
 SPs 14-17 years old will go to SXQ615. SPs 18+ years will go to SXQ700.

SXQ753 Genital human papillomavirus (HPV) is the most common sexually transmitted infection 
(STI). The virus infects the skin and mucous membranes. There are more than 40 HPV 
types that can infect the genital areas of men and women, including the skin of the penis, 
vulva (area outside the vagina), and anus, and the linings of the vagina, cervix, and rectum. 
 Approximately 20 million Americans are currently infected with HPV, and another 6.2 million people become newly infected each year. At least 50 percent of sexually active men 
and women acquire genital HPV infection at some point in their lives.

 4-250  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020       
 4-251  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   4.5 Critical Data Items (CDI)  
Critical data items (CDI) are verified and/or collected for SPs 12 years of age and older in the final 
section of the MEC interview. For most SPs this information will have been collected previously by one of the field interviewers. At the time of the MEC interview, it is your responsibility to attempt data collection for all missing items and to verify the existing information for selected items. 
Verify  
Street Address The CDI section begins with a request to verify the SP’s street address. Verify that the existing information is correct and make any changes, as necessary. 
Enter the address in the appropriate fields as follows: 
• Additional Address Line: Use this field to enter additional address information that is not 
a street address. Examples include a university name, a nursing home name, or the name of an apartment complex. You should also use this field if a subject receives mail in care of another person (e.g., c/o John Jones). 
• Street #, Dir Pre, Street Name, St/Rd/Ave, Dir Post: Enter the street number in the first data field on this line. When applicable, select the appropriate directional prefix or suffix (N, S, NE, SW, etc.) from the drop-down menu in the second and fifth data fields. Enter the complete street name in the third data field. Use the drop-down menu in the fourth field to select the street type (e.g., ST, RD, AVE, etc.). 
• Unit/Apt./Bldg.: Use this field in conjunction with Unit # to indicate whether the number refers to an apartment, lot, room, suite, building, etc. 
• Unit #: Enter the actual apartment (room, suite, bldg., etc.) unit number in this field. 
• PO Box, RRHC #, RRHC Box: When applicable, enter a post office box number in the first field, a rural route number in the second field, and a rural post office box number in the third field. If a PO box number or Rural Route number is added and there is a street address, there will be a prompt to “Remove the street address.” Delete the street address as directed. 
• City, State, Zip: Enter the full name of the city in the first field. Use the drop-down menu 
in the second field to select the appropriate state abbreviation. Enter the full six-digit ZIP 
code plus the four-digit suffix, when known. 
After verifying the street address, determine whether the SP’s mailing address is the same as his or her 
street address and whether he or she lived at his or her current address at the time of the screener interview.     
 4-252  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020   
 
 
 
    
 4-253  MEC Interviewers Procedures 2020    Click the arrow in the bottom right hand corner to bring up the next appropriate screen. If 
the mailing address differs from the street address, the program displays the “Verify Mailing

 5-1  MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  
  5. Mental Health Referrals  
This chapter describes the role of the mobile examination center (MEC) interviewer in identifying 
and documenting situations that warrant a referral to the MEC physician.  
5.1 Referral Procedures  
Certain information volunteered or reported during the MEC Interview should prompt a referral to the MEC physician. These situations are listed in Section 5.2. When the interviewer exits the Blaise 
CAPI instrument, th e application will extract the DPQ.090 response and automatically post a mental 
health observation to the physician, alerting the physician that the examinee needs to be seen prior 
to leaving the MEC. The physician is responsible for assessing the mental health problem and facilitating a referral, when needed.  
5.2 Situations Requiring a Mental Health Referral  
Study participants (SPs) aged 12 years and older will be referred to the MEC physician prior to 
leaving the examination center in the following circum stances:  
• During the Depression section (DPQ) of the Blaise CAPI interview, the SP reports that 
in the past two weeks , there have been several days or more when the SP had thoughts 
that he or she would be better off dead or  the SP had thoughts about hurting himself or 
herself (i.e., SP responds “several days” [code 1], “more than half the days” [code 2], or 
“nearly every day” [code 3] to DPQ.090.)  
• The participant becomes visibly upset while answering the question about suicide (e.g., crying, unable to answer  question). 
5.3 Generating a Mental Health Observation 
Whenever you encounter any of the situations listed in Section 5.2, a mental health observation to 
the physician must be generated. When you exit the Blaise CAPI instrument, the application will 
extrac t the DPQ.090 response and automatically post a mental health observation to the physician if 
the response/code to DPQ.090 is greater than zero.     
 5-2  MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  
  A physician observation must be entered manually if either of the following is true: 
• The participant becomes v isibly upset while answering the question about suicide, but 
answers “not at all” to the suicide question. 
• The participant becomes too upset to answer the suicide question. 
To manually enter an observation to the physician, select “Utilities” and “Observat ions” (as shown 
in the next screen) in the menu bar immediately after closing out the Blaise CAPI portion of the 
interview.

window (below).

  5.4 Mental Health Referral Process  
The MEC Interview, Physician , and Coordinator systems  work together in the mental health referral 
process. During the MEC Interview, SPs are asked the question “ Over the last 2 weeks, how often 
have you been bothered by the following problem: Thoughts that you would be bette r off dead or 
of hurting yourself in some way?” When the  interviewer codes the SP ’s response as “ several days, ” 
“more than half the days,” or “ nearly every day, ” ISIS posts a mental health (MH)  observation in the 
database as soon as the MEC Interview appli cation is closed.

 6-1  MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  
  6. Quality Control 
Quality control for the Mobile E xamination C enter (MEC) Interview consists of three main 
activities: data edits, observation/review of actual interviews, and data monitoring and review. 
6.1 Data Edits  
The MEC Interview  data are keyed directly into an automated data entry system. Each of the four 
sections of the MEC Interview  (CAPI, CFQ, A udio-CASI  or ACASI , and CDI) contains built-in 
error and consistency checks, al though the number and type of checks vary across each  section. 
Checks may include range and valid response checks, skip pattern or branching checks, and checks 
for logical relationships. Depending upon the section, checks may be either soft or hard edits. Soft edits alert the interviewer to a potential error or problem but allow the interviewer to proceed after 
confirming that the entered value(s) are correct. Hard edits prohibit the interviewer from continuing 
with the interview until the error has been corrected.  
6.2 Observation and Review of Interviews  
NHANES home office and National C enter for Health S tatistics (NCHS)  staff will observe a small 
number of live interviews for each MEC interviewer. The purpose of the observations is to determine whether appropriate interviewing techniques are being used. The observer will refer to a 
standard checklist of items (Exhibit 6- 1) against which the interviewer will be evaluated. Among the 
items the observer will assess are ability to gain and maintain rapport, use of appropriate probes, 
ability to respond to study participant ( SP) questions, and accurate entry of data. 
Interviewers are also recorded electronically by the MEC Interview application for review by home 
office staff. Recorded interviews are evaluated using the same evaluation criteria as interviews that 
are observed live.  
Any problems identified during either observation or review of recorded interviews will be brought to the interviewer’s attention and corrected.     
 6-2  MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  
  Exhibit 6 -1. NHANES MEC Interviewer Evalu ation Form  
6.2.1  Procedures for Recording the Interview  
After logging the SP into the interview, a consent screen will appear. The c onsent screen will be 
recorded; therefore, you will need to position the microphone close to the SP before you begin 
readi ng the consent screen. Note that should the interviewer feel that the offer of recording the 
interview may jeopardize the interview, they can indicate “Did Not Offer”  to bypass the audio-
recording screens.  However, the standard procedure should be to read this script to all respondents. 
After reading the consent screen, i f the respondent does not agree, or if the option to record the 
interview was not offered to the SP, the intervie w will proceed without recording.

r SPs age d 12- 17 years , parents/guardians will be asked for consent to record their child’s

parent/guardian did not consent, the consent screen will not appear and the child’s interview will proceed without recording . Interviews for SPs under the age of 12 are not recorded.

  6.2.2  Functionality in the CAPI Section  
The CAPI section allows the interviewer to manually pause and restart  the recording, as well as, 
completely stop and save the recording. This feature is not available in the  ACASI section. 
You will notice that the toolbar in the CAPI section has three colored buttons (below).  
The
 audio recording service application has been designed to perform the following functions: 
• Pause recording. 
– The yellow button will pause an active recording. Once paused, the system will 
indicate that the recording has been paused with this message: 
– If a recording is paused and the interviewer advances to the next screen without 
unpausing the recording, a message box will appear with the following message: 
– When you press the OK button you will proceed to the next question. This is so you will not forget to restart  a recording while in the interview.  
• Resume recording. 
– The green button will resume the paused recording.    
 6-5  MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  
  • Stop recording. 
– The red button will stop and save the current recording. You will get this message 
if you click on the Stop button: 
– If you select “No,”  you will continue recording. If you select “ Yes,” you will stop 
recording and will not be able to start it again. 
You will also note that the toolbar has an additional Recording Menu. Here you may also  select from 
the drop-down menu to Pause, Resume, or Stop recording. 
 Fu
nctionality in the ACASI Section 
In the ACASI section, you will not have the option to pause, resume, or stop the recording in the 
toolbar. If the SP has agreed to have the interview recorded, however, the system will record the 
interview.  
6.3 Data Monitoring and Review  
The home office will evaluate completed MEC Interview s to look for problem interviews 
(incompletes, refusals, extremely long interviews, etc.), additional interviewer notes, and comments.

interview administration times. 7. Cognitive Functioning Scoring Application

and enter  your username and password, and click the “Login” button (Exhibit 7- 1).

7.2 Main Menu  
The CFQ appointment screen  is a queue of all of the cognitive functioning tests that are available to 
score  (Exhibit 7- 3). The Appointment screen has eight sortable columns—date of the exam, 
appointment ID, session ID, SP ID, language, flagged for review, status, and scorer. The “flagged 
for review” column will indicate if a case has been flagged for home office review by the scorer. The “status” column will show “In Progress” if a case has been started but not finished and 
“Mismatched” if a case has been scored by both scorers but the scores do not match. The “scorer” 
column will show a “1” if the person logged is the same person who conducted the interview (i.e., scorer 1) and a “2” if the person logged in did not conduct the interview (i.e., scorer 2). To sort the columns, click on the column header. 
To open a case in the queue to start the scoring process, s elect a case from the list and click the 
“Score” button. 
7-2  MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  Exhibit 7 -3. Appointment screen  
7.3 The Scoring Application 
Ideally, the interviewer who has conducted the assessment will score the MoCA -SA as soon after its 
completion as possible. Not only does timel y scoring allow for an interviewer to recall details unique 
to the SP or testing session, but if there are technical issues with the recording that may impact 
subsequent recordings, ISIS staff can be notified. 
7.3.1  Common Screen Features  
The scoring screens have certain features in common. These include a “review” check  box, a 
comment box, a recording control box, and a data entry field. 
7-3  MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  Scorers may flag a test for review if they have questions or concerns about a recording or item by 
checking the “Review?” check  box on the screen. Items flagged for review will be reviewed by the 
component specialist. 
All screens have a comment box , which allows the interviewer to record comments about the exam 
or recording. The component specialist will review these comments during QC or adjudication. 
Please note that these comments are not reviewed immediately, so anything that needs urgent attention should be relayed to home office staff using another method. 
Each screen has  a recording control box that allows the interviewer to control the recording. Use the 
play/pause buttons to navigate the recordings as necessary. A recording status bar moves along as 
the recording plays (Exhibit 7-4). Click and drag the bar to rewind or fast-forward the recording. The volume of the recording can also be adjusted by dragging the volume button up and down. 
When listening to recordings, make sure the volume on the computer is also turned up. 
Exhibit 7 -4. Recording control box  
So
me screens have an image associated with it. If a screen has an image, a link will display on the 
screen. Click the link to open the image. The image opens in a separate window and allows you to 
zoom in and out. 
7.3.2  Exiting and Saving Scores  
If you need to exit a case before you finish scoring, you can save the scoring you have done on one screen by advancing to the next screen. To exit a case early, click the “home” or “logout” button. 
Partially scored cases will appear at the top  of the scoring queue. 
When you click “complete” on the last screen (Memory – Delayed Recall), a pop -up message 
appears to confirm that you want to complete the case (Exhibit 7- 5). Clicking “OK” will remove the 
case from your queue and it will only return if there is a mismatch.  
7-4  MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  Exhibit 7 -5. Complete confirmation pop- up box  
The
 scoring application automatically logs the user out after an extended period of inactivity. 
7.3.3  Mismatches  
Interviewers will score the MoCA -SAs that he/she conducted as well as the MoCA-SAs conducted 
by the other MEC Interviewer at each stand. If there is  a score discrepancy (i.e., the score by 
scorer  1 does not match the score by scorer 2), the test will be put back in to the queue for both 
interviewers to resolve together , and marked as a mismatch in the status column on the 
Appointment screen. Mismatched  cases will appear at the top  of the scoring queue. If a discrepancy 
cannot be resolved after three attempts , the test will be removed from the scorers’ queues and 
reviewed by the component specialist.  Any unscored or mismatched cases in the scorers’ queue s 
when the stand closes will be scored or adjudicated by home office staff.  
If a case is marked as “mismatch,” only the mismatch screens will display when the case is opened. 
In the top right corner of the screen is a score dashboard. The score dashboard i ndicates what 
screens have matching scores and what screens have mismatch scores (Exhibit 7 -6). 
Scorers should carefully listen to the recordings and review the images, if necessary, on each screen 
and rescore the case. If the case reappears in the queue as a mismatch, the scorers should discuss the 
discrepancy and try to settle it. After discussion, if the scorers do not agree on how to score, they should re- open the case and make their final selections. The case will be removed from the queue 
even if the mismatch still exists.  
7-5  MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  Exhibit 7 -6. Mismatch score dashboard  
7.4 Scoring the CFQ Exam  
The cognitive functioning assessment (MoCA- SA) consists of 14 tasks. The tasks are questions or 
problems to solve. You will be transcribing results from the recordings for 12 tasks (questions or 
problems that required oral responses) and evaluating the results of two written tasks. In the scoring 
application, each of the tasks appear on a separate screen. The scoring criteria for each task is 
described, and based on your evaluation of the recording and/or written task, you will determine how it should be coded. The actual score will be algorithm-based. 
For several items, coding consists of two parts: ( 1) Typing stated responses, and ( 2) Coding as 
correct or incorrect. At times you may be required to listen to the recording of a specific task several 
times to transcribe it in full. 
For all questions in the assessment, m ark “refused” if the SP refuses to try.  Mark “don’t know” if 
the SP says they don’t know after asking them  to guess or if they can’t make a guess.  For questions 
with drawings, scorers must listen to the recording in addition to reviewing the drawing. The 
recording in addition to the scanned image will help in making a determination. 
After completing the scoring of each task, click the “NEXT” button to save the results and continue 
to the next screen.

7-9  MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  7.4.4  Clock Drawing  
DESCRIPTION:  Evaluate three  parts of the clock drawing (the contour, the numbers, and the 
hands) and give an overall score (Exhibit 7- 10). 
Exhibit 7 -10. Clock Drawing scoring screen  
7- 10 MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  SCORING INSTRUCTIONS: Each part of the clock must be examined carefully. It is not 
unusual for a cl ock drawing to appear correct at first glance. Please take your time and inspect each 
part of the clock. To view the scanned image of the clock, click the link.  If the respondent makes 
multiple attempts to draw the clock, score the clock with the most comp lete attempt.  
CORRECT RESPONSE – EVALUATING THE CONTOUR:  
Inspect the contour of the clock for the following: 
• The contour is present and is either a circle or a square.  
– Contours in the shapes of diamonds, squares, trapezoids, and rectangles are  
counted if the shape looks as though the shape was deliberately drawn that way.  
• Only minor distortion in the contour of the clock is acceptable  
– Slight imperfection on closing the circle (i.e., lines were not closed but there was 
only a small gap in between the lines ). 
– Not too oval- shaped, skewed, or flattened . 
POTENTIAL SCORE:  1 point. 
CORRECT RESPONSE – EVALUATING THE NUMBERS:  
Inspect the numbers on the clock for the following: 
• All of the numbers (1-12) are present and there are no additional numbers included. 
– Numbers can  be marked as dashes or dots or a combination of dots, dashes and 
numbers as long as they follow the requirements below. 
• Numbers are:  
– Upright 
– In the correct order 
– In the approximate quadrant 
1. Quadrants are  defined based on the shape of the contour and not the shape 
of the number placement. 
7- 11 MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  – Placed consistently inside or outside the contour 
– Arranged in a circular manner  
• Standard or Roman numerals are acceptable.  
If the SP did not align the 12 with the top of the page , evaluate the clock using the location of the 12 
as the top of the clock. 
POTENTIAL SCORE:  1 point. 
CORRECT RESPONSE – EVALUATING THE HANDS:  
Inspect the hands of the clock for the following: 
• There are two hands present.  
• The hands are of different lengths – the hour hand is clearly shorter than the minute 
hand. 
– When hands are  arguably the same length, hands may still be counted as correct if 
the minute hand is  significantly closer than the hour hand to the numbers. 
– If the hands are labeled “hour hand” and “ minute hand,” ignore these labels and 
grade the clock hands  based on length as usual. 
– The labels “long” and “short” are  considered self -corrections to the hands and 
should be marked correct if “long” indicate s the minute hand and “short” 
indicates the hour hand. 
• The hands indicate the correct time – the short hand points at the 11 and the long hand points at the 2. 
– If the SP  draws a line from the 12 to the center of the clock face in addition to 
the clock hands, the line can be judged to be a “guideline” and not an error if it i s 
stylistically distinct from the clock hands  (e.g., arrows drawn on clock hands). 
– If the SP draws the hour hand pointing to slightly after 11, count this as correct, since this occurs in analog (not digital)  clocks . 
• The hands are centered within the clock’s surface with their junction close to the center of the clock. 
POTENTIAL SCORE:  1 point.

DESCRIPTION:  Record all correct F words named in one minute according to the rules given 
(Exhibit 7 -20). 
Exhibit 7 -20. Verbal Fluency – Letter F scoring screen  
SCO
RING INSTRUCTIONS: 
• Type the correct words beginning with the letter “F” that you hear on the recording. 
• An internal look-up dictionary database (English and Spanish) has been installed for 
your convenience. As you type words, a list of words appears under the data entry field 
7- 24 MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  to help with spelling. You can finish typing the word or select the word from the list 
(Exhibit 7 -21). 
Exhibit 7 -21. Sentence Repetition scoring screen  
– Note:  The look-up dictionary contains many “F” words but you must use the 
rules below to determine if the word the SP says should be counted. For example, 
the SP may say fun” and “funny” or “feliz” and “felicidad”. Both sets of words 
will appear in the look-up dictionary but our rules indicate that we cannot count both words. The reason is explained below. 
• When you start typing, the recording will automatically pause. When you press “enter” or select a word from the look- up dictionary, the recording will automatically restart.  
• List words in the reported order to make  it easier for our review.  To move words to a  
different position in the list, s imply select the word you want to move, and  click the up 
or down button on the right side of the data entry box to move the word to the correct position.  
CORRECT RESPONSE – SCORING RULES: 
The instructions for what F words cannot be counted were given to SP, and you will basically follow 
these  same  “rules,” Further details and explanations are provided: 
• Only record words that begin with the letter “F.” Remember there are words that begin 
with the letter “F” in Spanish, but “PH” in English (example: filosophy/philosophy). 
7- 25 MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  • If the SP switches between English and Spanish words that begin with the letter “F,” 
record the “F” words in both languages. 
• Sometimes the same word is repeated more than once. Only accept it the first time.  
Words that have previously been entered (duplicate words) are highlighted but it will 
not prevent you from typing in more words (Exhibit 7-22). Duplicate words can be 
deleted right away or before continuing to the next screen. A “Delete” button  allows the 
scorer to remove duplicates or fix typing errors. 
Exhibit 7 -22. Duplicate words highlighted 
• I
t’s sometimes hard to differentiate spoken words like: full and fool; full and fill; feel 
and feed; or to hear when an –ed is added; for example ‘fatigued.’ All of these words are 
correct so if there is a mismatch and both scorers agre e that the word the SP said could 
be either of the words you recorded, agree to pick one of the two you think it could be and settle the mismatch.  It is not necessary to send it for adjudication in this scenario. 
• If a word is mispronounced but you can decipher it, include it and type it with proper spelling. For example, it sounds like “fatigued” but the SP said it as “fartigued.” Type “fatigued.” 
• Homophones are words that sound the same, and have different meanings and different spellings. Some examples are: fair, fare; flour, flower; fore, four, for – more common in English than Spanish. 
– Record the spelling of the first word in the look-up dictionary to avoid a mismatch or need for reconciliation unless the SP spells the word for you. For example, “fair” i s before “fare” in the look up dictionary. 
7- 26 MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  – If the SP specifically tells you the spelling or meaning of the words, record and 
count both as correct. For example, the SP says “flour as in grain for bread,” and 
“flower as in the plant.” 
• Some numbers can be counted. 
– Numb ers such as “four” and “fourteen” or “fifty”  and “fifty -one” are  considered 
as having the same root but different endings so only the first one said is to be counted. 
– Numbers such as “four” and “fifteen” are each counted.  
• Proper nouns do not count. (Proper nouns have two distinct features: They name specific one-of-a-kind items, and they begin with capital letters, no matter whe re they 
occur within a sentence.  All nouns are words naming people, animals, places, things, 
and ideas. Every noun can be further classified as either common or proper .
1) 
– Exceptions to this rule are words with alternate definitions or in common use: Fahrenheit, Ford, Fiat, Ferris wheel, Frank, Frisbee  
– Be aware of possible proper nouns that are not names; for example, “F antasia” is 
the name of a Disney movie; also a woman’s name.  
• Words with the same root as a previous word but a different suffix are not counted 
– Examples (only one can be counted): fool/foolish, fall/falling, fun/funny, fire/ fired, forgot/forgotten, felon/felony, future/futuristic 
– Exceptions: When words are judged to refer to substantially different concepts. 
For example, favor/favorite, frank/frankfurter, fellow/fellowship, fire/fireman/  
fireplace/firehouse are all counted as separate words.  
• Foreign language words that may not yet have been added to the dictionary should be 
scored as correct if they are recognizable (e.g., fromage, frijoles).  
• If there is a question about whether or not to count a word, the scorers should look it up or contact a supervisor and leave a note about it in the comment box. 
• Scorers should give the SP “the benefit of the doubt” in questionable situations; for 
example when an SP has a thick English accent (i.e., English is not the first language) or Spanish accent that may not be familiar.

Sc
oring Rules for Tests Administered in Spanish:  
• For English-speaking respondents, “February” is a proper noun and therefore is not counted. However, “febrero” (Spanish for “February”) is not considered a proper noun 
(according to Spanish grammar), so it is counted as a word for Spanish-speaking 
respondents. 
• For English-speaking responde nts, “Fritos”  (as in the brand name of corn chips) is 
considered a proper noun and therefore not counted. However, “frito” (Spanish for “fried”) is not a proper noun, so it is counted as a word for Spanish-speaking respondents. 
• As in the English language protocol, words with the same root as a previous word are  
not counted, even if they have different suffixes or conjugations. For example, do not count both the words “flor” and “florecita” or “feliz” and “felicidad.”

Launching the Spanish MEC Interview 
  
   
 A.1-1 MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  
  Appendix A.1  
Launching the Spanish MEC Interview  
After logging the study participant into the MEC Interview as described in Section 3.5, the 
application allows you to select the interview language. In the toolbar under “Utilities”  you can set 
the interview language to either English or Spanish. Please note : this sets the language for the 
Permission to Record statement, Cognitive Functioning introduction, ACASI introduction, and 
Critical Data section of the interview. The language can be changed again, if necessary, on the 
Permission to Record statement, Cognitive Functioning introduction, ACASI introduction, and Critical Data screens by clicking on “ Utilities”  on the toolbar and selecting a different language.  
To set or switch the language of the Blaise ™ CAPI interview, select F2 or “Options”  then “Form 
language”  from the  Blaise menu bar. Choose “ENG English” to display the questions in English 
or “SPN Spanish” to display the questions in Spanish. 
 
   
 A.1-2 MEC Interviewers Proc edures 2020  
  To switch the language of the help text associated with an item, select “Options”  then “Form 
language.”  Choose “TEXT Spanish Help”  to display the help text in Spanish. Choose “HELP 
Help”  to display the Help text in English. 
Once ACASI is launched, the first screen allows you to select the language of the ACASI screens  
and corresponding voice files. 
To chang
e the language after  the ACASI interview has started, right click on the mouse, select “Go 
To” and “Start” to go back to the first ACASI screen and change the language. Touch the “N ext” 
button on the touch screen until you return to where you left off. Appendix A .2

HELP SCREEN SHOULD READ:  Aborto espontáneo: se refiere a un embarazo que termina naturalmente 
durante los primeros 5 meses (20 semanas) de embarazo. Nacimiento muerto: se refiere a un bebé que nace muerto después de 6 o más meses (20 o más semanas) de embarazo. Embarazo extrauterino: se refiere a un embarazo que ocurre en las trompas de Falopio. Aborto: se refiere a un embarazo que se termina durante los 6 meses de embarazo usando métodos de inducción. Los métodos incluyen extracción con aspiradora o sea succión, inyecciones salinas y “D y L” o sea dilatación y legrado o raspado uterino.

NO .................................................................  2 (RHQ.421)

  The language chosen in the drop-down menu box will be preselected on the first ACASI screen. 
You can change the language that was preselected by touching the button with the language you want and s electing “N ext.” 
To
 chang
e the language after the ACASI interview has started, right click on the mouse, select “ Go 
To” and “ Start” to go back to the first ACASI screen and change the language. Touch the “N ext” 
button on the touch screen until you return to where you left off.
